Project Name: Chile Fund against Hunger and Poverty
Description: The project aimed to alleviate poverty and hunger primarily in Chile by financing and supporting projects that promote sustainable livelihoods, social protection, and food security for vulnerable populations. The fund also works to strengthen local capacities, promote participation and collaboration among different actors, and provide technical assistance and knowledge exchange with other countries. The Government of Chile shared its social and economic transformation experience with other countries (Gaza, Mali, South Sudan, and over 30 countries) through South-South cooperation that can accelerate social and economic progress.The Fund has awarded over $12 million to 82 South-South cooperation projects in over 30 countries in Africa, LAC, and the Pacific.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Government of Chile (Chilean International Cooperation Agency)
Thematic Areas: Agriculture and Food Security,Poverty and Inequality

Project Name: Industrialization and Job Creation for Africa
Description: The project aimed to promote sustainable industrialization and job creation in Africa by enhancing regional cooperation, attracting investment, and strengthening local capacities. The initiative focuses on developing key sectors such as agro-processing, light manufacturing, and renewable energy, and provides technical assistance, knowledge exchange, and financing to support industrialization and job creation efforts. The partnership in this project are built on collaboration between African countries (Ethiopia, Djibouti, Nigeria) with comparative advantages in the supply of labour and raw materials to attract investors from emerging economies with manufacturing capability and international buyers/retailers in Europe and the United States. UNDP China signed a memorandum of understanding with the Made in Africa Initiative in 2015 to build on early success. The Centre for New Structural Economics at Peking University and the Made in Africa Initiative are working with UNDP to leverage its global network and convening power to advance the agenda of pan-African industrialization. Chinese companies participated in the project to make Africa the next manufacturing hub for global markets by helping it to seize the opportunity for industrialization arising from the relocation of light manufacturing from China.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,UNIDO,Made in Africa Initiative,Centre for New Structural Economics at Peking University,African Governments,Companies.

Project Name: New Rice for Africa (NERICA)
Description: The project aimed to improve food security and livelihoods in Africa by developing and promoting new rice varieties that are high-yielding, disease-resistant, and adapted to local conditions. It also provided technical assistance, capacity building, and knowledge exchange to support the development and dissemination of NERICA varieties, which have been shown to increase rice productivity and incomes for smallholder farmers. Regular field visits are organized to build farmers_ capacities. Knowledge and information about technologies are shared among farmers on a regular basis. Financial and market risk implications are analysed. Rural knowledge centres are set up to facilitate peer learning among farmers from neighbouring communities with similar land conditions. Japan funded the project.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Japan,UNOSSC,UNDP,the African Development Bank,CGIAR

Project Name: Family Protection, Support, Security and Justice for Victims of Domestic and Gender-based Violence Programme
Description: The programme supported the Government of Iraq in undertaking policy, legislative, social and economic reforms to enhance the response of national institutions, improve access to justice, and empower victims of domestic violence and gender-based violence. UNDP facilitated South-South knowledge transfers, workshops and study tours to enable Iraqi authorities to learn from their Jordanian counterparts how to establish family protection systems, facilitate law enforcement and ensure access to justice for victims. UNDP supported the project as the coordinating agency in collaboration with UNICEF, UNFPA and UN-Women. The Governments of Denmark and Norway provided financial support.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Implementing partners in Iraq included the Family Protection Units at the federal level and the Directorate for Tracing Violence against Women at the regional level. Other participating national partners included the Ministry of Women__ Affairs,the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs,the Ministry of Interior,the Ministry of Human Rights,the Ministry of the Environment,the Ministry of Health,the High Council of Women in Kurdistan and civil society organizations. In Jordan,the Ministry of Social Development and the Jordanian Family Protection Department were part of the Public Security Directorate. UNDP supported the project as the coordinating agency in collaboration with UNICEF,UNFPA and UN-Women. The Governments of Denmark and Norway provided financial support.

Project Name: Gender-sensitive Social Protection Floors
Description: The initiative aimed to create a platform (https://socialprotection.org/) and provide social protection to vulnerable populations in developing countries, with a particular focus on women and girls. It involved providing cash transfers, food assistance, and other forms of support to those in need. By making project information available online or through events, publications and web platforms (including in particular the Global South- South Development Academy web platform, http:// academy.ssc.undp.org, and the ILO Social Protection Platform, www.social-protection.org), more countries are now learning from these experiences and findings. The project was implemented in close collaboration with United Nations resident coordinators and country teams under the auspices of UNDP/UNDG and other United Nations organizations. The direct recipients of the South-South exchanges were representatives from relevant ministries, decentralized government, social partners, social security institutions and other stakeholders involved in social protection from the participating countries. The project did this by supporting the systematic, cross-country transfer of knowledge, skills and expertise in the area of social protection. The following are some examples of how the exchanges proved fruitful. The experience of Thailand in strengthening the health protection system and extending health protection was useful for both the health insurance fund and the strategy to extend into Cambodia and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. The experiences of Brazil, India, Mongolia and others in setting up a coordination mechanism and/or single database of beneficiaries were useful for Cambodia__ social service delivery mechanism also currently being piloted. The experience of India in monitoring and evaluating protocols for social protection schemes proved useful for Cambodia__ new delivery mechanism currently being piloted. The assessment-based national dialogue tool that supports the identification of costed scenarios to extend social protection and facilitate the decision-making process was developed, tested, applied and fine-tuned through South-South exchanges. In Cambodia, national stakeholders learned from countries_ experiences in setting up a coordination mechanism following the single-window service approach (Brazil, India and Mongolia) to facilitate outreach to rural populations. A monitoring and evaluation protocol was developed based on experiences from India, which helped to strengthen the national health insurance system and staff capacity- building. In the Lao People__ Democratic Republic, exchanges were productive in supporting the extension of social health protection through the development of the Social Security Law (2013), national health insurance scheme regulations, pilot scheme technical guidelines (2015), and capacity-building of national stakeholders including the new National Social Security Fund.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNOSSC,ILO,UNDG,UNDP

Project Name: Rural Energy Development Programme
Description: The project aimed to increase access to modern energy services in rural areas. It involved promoting the use of renewable energy sources such as solar power and biofuels, as well as increasing access to energy-efficient technologies.  This project offered a global network of expertise and experiences on which countries can draw to tackle their rural energy development challenges. It has already informed several countries in Asia (Afghanistan, Bhutan, Cambodia, Mongolia, Pakistan and Tajikistan) in various programmes relating to energy and local service delivery. Other countries, such as Kenya, Uganda and the United Republic of Tanzania, have also benefited from three-month, on-site training by Nepalese micro- hydropower experts to facilitate the replication of the approach. Danmark was a donor.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Nepal Electricity Authority,Government of Nepal,Danish International Development Agency (DANIDA),UNDP,World Bank,local banks and communities

Project Name: LAC Free of Child Labour Regional Initiative
Description: The project aimed to eliminate child labour in the region. It involved promoting education and training opportunities for children, as well as working with governments, employers, and civil society to improve laws and policies related to child labour. The Initiative provides an excellent platform for scaling up SSTC projects among member countries and other regions and has the potential for replication in other regions of the world. Spain and Brazil are providers, and LAC 26 states exchanged ideas and experiences. The Initiative and its technical secretariat closely coordinate with other United Nations organizations through the Regional Inter-agency Group on Child Labour, which is led by ILO and includes UNDP, UNICEF, UNESCO, UNFPA, WHO, FAO and UN-Women. In order to facilitate the exchange of good practices, the virtual platform of the Initiative includes a specific tool that maps South-South cooperation capacities of each country: http://www.oit.org.br/acelerar
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Spanish Agency for Development Cooperation,Junta de Andalucía/Agencia Andaluza de Cooperación Internacional para el Desarrollo,Brazilian Cooperation Agency,ILO,UNDP,UNICEF,UNESCO,UNFPA,WHO,FAO and UN-Women.

Project Name: Songhai Centres
Description: The peoject aimed to promote sustainable agriculture and rural development in West Africa. It involved establishing training centers, with the support of  China, VietNam and Thailand, where farmers could learn about sustainable agriculture practices and business management. The Songhai model is changing the way in which rural communities in many African countries share ideas and experiences, transfer technologies and train new generations in building sustainable farming practices at the grass-roots level. It is an integrated system of development, creating and building __reen rural cities_ designed to tackle the triple challenge of environment, sustainable food production/poverty and youth unemployment, and reversing rural exodus. The technologies used are developed through cooperation with China, Thailand and Viet Nam and many African universities and institutions.The Songhai model is being replicated in 15 African countries, building on its growing numbers of incubated entrepreneurs who reinvest in their communities to create new opportunities.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Governments,private sector,Eliminate Poverty NOW,French Development Agency,FAO,IFAD,ILO,Songhai Centre,Songhai Women__ Capital Fund,UNDP,USAID

Project Name: Viet Nam Cleaner Production Centre
Description: The project aimed to promote environmentally sustainable industrial development in Vietnam. It involved providing technical assistance and training to businesses on how to reduce their environmental impact and improve their efficiency. The Vietnam Cleaner Production Centre uses South-South technical exchanges to develop local capacities and bolster local institutions while it tests and adapts concepts from other countries. A strong capacity-building and training component ensures the assimilation and long- term sustainability of projects. The Centre also functions as a research and reference institution for the dissemination of best practices and learning. The Centre helps to strengthen national regulatory frameworks, for example, through the introduction of cleaner production laws and by establishing national centres of excellence in Cambodia, Lao People__ Democratic Republic and Vietnam.Through its activities in capacity-building and Resource Efficient and Cleaner Production (RECP) assessments in Cambodia and the Lao People__ Democratic Republic, it has helped to start up RECP centres in these two countries.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Main partners include local industries,small and medium-size enterprises,academia,ministries of industry,UNIDO,UNDP,UNEP,ILO,Switzerland,the European Union,SWITCH-Asia,RECPnet,B_CH KHOA,Hanoi University of Science and Technology,and industrial associations in Vietnam. Some of the partners are clients,donors or facilitators in approaching industries and in offering capacity-building courses.

Project Name: Saudi Youth Exchange Programme
Description: The project aimed to promote cross-cultural exchange and understanding among young people in Saudi Arabia. It involved facilitating exchange programs between young people from different regions of the country. This project maintained connections with and among these future leaders could be important for future South-South cooperation partnerships and strategic collaborations. Also, the outcome document from the programme serves as a basis for other potential South-South and triangular cooperation initiatives on specific topics of bilateral interest among countries. 10 youth exchange visits took place with various countries (Brazil, China, India, the Republic of South Korea, Spain and the United Republic of Tanzania).
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,Government of Saudi Arabia,the Private sector

Project Name: China__ One-stop Service Centre Model: Designing Government Services for Urban Bangladesh
Description: Apart from streamlining government services and improving efficiency, the project also included a significant digitalization component.This aspect aimed to leverage technology to enhance the accessibility and convenience of government services for citizens. Bangladesh conducted South-South exchanges with China in 2013 to learn from and adapt its innovative one-stop social service centre model. UNDP facilitated and coordinated experts from Malaysia and Singapore.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,four mayors from Bangladesh,city administrations

Project Name: Energy-efficiency Standards and Labelling
Description: The project aimed to promote the use of energy-efficient appliances and equipment. It involved setting standards for energy efficiency and labeling products so that consumers could make informed choices about the products they buy. Bangladesh, Indonesia and Pakistan, which initially had no or limited Energy-efficiency Standards and Labelling (ESL) activities, benefited from the project__ South-South knowledge and lessons learned, capacity-building activities and tools on ESL developed by countries with greater accumulated experiences, primarily China but also Thailand and Viet Nam.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF Small Grants Programme

Project Name: Caribbean Risk Management Initiative
Description: The project aimed to improve disaster risk management in the Caribbean. It involved developing plans and policies to reduce the impact of natural disasters, as well as providing training and resources to help communities prepare for and respond to disasters. UNDP helped Cuba to replicate its experience in other countries (Dominican Republic, Guyana, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, British Virgin Islands). This South-South cooperation initiative has proved successful and adaptable in all participating countries while taking into consideration their local contexts.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP

Project Name: Benguela Current Commission
Description: The project aimed to promote the sustainable management and conservation of the Benguela Current marine ecosystem by fostering regional cooperation among Angola, Namibia, and South Africa. The commission facilitated collaboration among governments, scientists, and stakeholders to enhance the understanding of the ecosystem, promote sustainable fisheries, and address climate change impacts. Government leaders from Angola, Namibia and South Africa have jointly established the transboundary Benguela Current Commission to promote a coordinated regional approach to the long-term conservation. It is considered an outstanding model of South-South cooperation that benefits countries throughout the region. Other regions and countries have already picked up on the Benguela example, such as the Humboldt Current Large Marine Ecosystem Project, the African large marine ecosystem projects (for the Canary, Guinea, Agulhas and Somali currents), the fisheries refugia in the South China Sea, and the Global Ballast (GloBallast) Water Management Programme. The replication of the model hinges on close cooperation and the funding of participating countries.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Global Environment Facility (GEF),UNDP,Benguela Current Commission and participating countries

Project Name: Regional Initiative for Capacity Enhancement in South Sudan
Description: The project aimed to enhance the capacity of civil servants in South Sudan by providing training and technical assistance in key areas such as public financial management, procurement, and human resource management; and supported the development of a professional and competent civil service that can effectively deliver services to the citizens. Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda deployed to South Sudan 200 civil servants in key functions identified by the Government of South Sudan. This was an example of triangular-organized, donor-supported South-South cooperation in coaching and mentoring for civil service capacity. The model has been gradually promoted for fragile states (IGAD countries).
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Norway,Intergovernmental Authority on Development,Government of South Sudan,UNDP South Sudan,USAID,German Agency for International Development (GIZ),Kenya

Project Name: Digital Centres
Description: The project aimed to promote digital inclusion and access to information and communication technologies (ICTs) in developing countries by establishing digital centers in rural and underserved areas, by learning from Bangladesh (a2i). The initiative aimed to bridge the digital divide and promote economic and social development by providing access to ICTs, training, and digital services. Government and non-government agencies from the Maldives, Bhutan and Fiji have already entered into partnerships with a2i to replicate some of its successful initiatives, including the digital centre initiative.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Government of Bangladesh,UNDP and USAID,Access to Information (a2i) Programme

Project Name: TRANSFORM
Description: The primary objective of TRANSFORM was  to build critical thinking and capacities of policymakers and practitioners at national and decentralized levels to improve the design, effectiveness and efficiency of social protection systems. This is achieved through South-South cooperation and peer learning among experts from participating countries (Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, South Africa, the United Republic of Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe), academia; ILO, UNICEF, UNDP, IPC-IG, Irish Aid and EU-SPS contributed to capacity development programmes.The first TRANSFORM Training of Trainers was conducted in October 2017 in Zambia. The 23 trainers represented government, academia, the private sector and the UN system from Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, South Africa, the United Republic of Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Participants were selected through a call for applications distributed through TRANSFORM regional partners_ networks. To obtain certification, trainers first participated in the training. In the second step, they provided a training themselves, with the support of the head trainers. This will enable the creation of a pool of trainers across Africa. A community of regional TRANSFORM trainers will facilitate interactions among Southern countries.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: African Union,UNICEF,UNDP,ILO,IPC-IG,EU-SPS,Irish Aid,Southern Africa Social Protection Experts Network-SASPEN

Project Name: Cuba and the Pacific: Fostering Organic Agriculture Across the Ocean
Description: The project aimed to promote South-South cooperation between Cuba and Pacific island countries in the areas of health, education, and disaster response. The initiative facilitated the exchange of knowledge and expertise to enhance the capacity of Pacific island countries to address their development challenges. During the training, El Salvador, Fiji, Guatemala and the Solomon Islands learned from Cuba on future South- South cooperation in the areas of organic farming, sustainability and resilience development in the fragile ecosystems of small island developing States.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF Small Grants Programme and Pacific Organic and Ethical Trade Community (POETCom)

Project Name: Supporting and Strengthening Sub-regional and post-Ebola Medical Surveillance and Socio-Economic Recovery in West Africa
Description: The project sought to tackle socio-economic issues and address public health preparedness needs that arose following the 2014-2016 Ebola outbreak in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. There were South-South cooperation at the regional level by building the capacity of West African institutions and training West African experts and practitioners through workshops conducted by these institutions. Also, there were transfer of good practices and knowledge within the ECOWAS region, in cross-border areas in Côte d__voire, Guinea, and Liberia, through a research institution based in Ghana. Japan was a partner of this project.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Government of Japan,UNDP.

Project Name: Regional cooperation as an effective tool in advancing gender equality
Description: The project aimed to promote gender equality and women's empowerment in MENA region by fostering regional cooperation and knowledge sharing. The initiative focused on areas such as women's economic empowerment. The project participants from the countries (Bosnia and Herzegovina, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia) participated workshops and created an online platform for the regional network of gender trainers of all four countries, under the auspices of UNDP/SEESAC, and used it for the knowledge exchange and sharing.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP/SEESAC,Ministries of Defence of Bosnia and Herzegovina,the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia,Montenegro,and Serbia

Project Name: Implementing Integrated Water Resource and Wastewater Management in Atlantic and Indian Ocean Small Island Developing States
Description: The project was designed to make each country demonstrate one innovative approach for achieving IWRM (Integrated Water Resources Management) and finally lead to freshwater and the healthy ecosystems. Six SIDS, nearly 100,000 community members have already benefitted from improved water quality, which improves health outcomes, facilitates climate change adaptation and mitigates the threat of natural and man-made hazards.The project allows six SIDS to see and learn from the results of six different approaches through South-South exchanges. Implementing Integrated Water Resources Management in the Atlantic and Indian Ocean Small Island Developing States (IWRM AIO SIDS), jointly implemented by UNDP and UN Environment Programme (UNEP), has worked to strengthen the commitment and capacity of the six participating countries in implementing an integrated, ecosystem- based approach to the management of freshwater resources. Results from the IWRM demonstration activities were included in policy discussions at the national level to ensure that national policies would embrace the IWRM approach for sustainability. São Tomé and Príncipe has enacted its first Water Act, fully based on the IWRM approach. The Seychelles also developed a national water policy, a national IWRM plan, and a draft national water act to fully embrace IWRM principles in its national legal and institutional arrangement water management. In the Maldives, the Government__ cabinet developed and endorsed a national water and sewerage policy. Mauritius also strengthened its groundwater monitoring capacity to improve its conjunctive management of groundwater and surface water resource and to protect the Northern Aquifer from saltwater intrusion. In Comoros and São Tomé and Príncipe, the project supported the development and implementation of an IWRM plan for the Mutsamudu River basin and significantly improved the management of the river catchment.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: GEF,UNDP,UNEP,UNOPS,Government of Cabo Verde,Comoros,Maldives,Mauritius,Sa_o Tome_ and Pri_ncipe,Seychelles

Project Name: China _ Ghana/Zambia South-South Cooperation on Renewable Energy Technology Transfer
Description: The project aimed to provide technical expertise, knowledge and technology transfer for renewable energy to these countries. This project has helped in reducing their dependency on fossil fuels and increasing access to sustainable energy. Workshops and  sessions were held in China, Ghana and Zambia to facilitate the exchange of best practice as well as to establish solid foundations for stakeholder alliances that include the private sector. Discussions are underway on replicating the projects in other countries, building on existing UNDP engagements. Countries and other stakeholders involved need strong coordination and willingness to cooperate and learn from each other__ experiences.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Denmark,UNDP,Respective Governments

Project Name: Partnership for Action on Green Economy
Description: The project aimed to promote sustainable and inclusive growth, particularly in Africa and Asia, through green economy initiatives. The project aimed to create job opportunities, reduce poverty and environmental degradation, and promote sustainable development. South-South and triangular cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Mongolia provided an opportunity to build and strengthen mutual exchange on green economy policy development and practice between the two neighbouring countries. Germany provided funding, and technical assistance.

Project Name: Bangladesh: Empathy Training
Description: a2i introduced empathy training, an innovative intervention empathy training inspired by Nesta__ design thinking model of innovation. Trainees are better able to relate to a citizen__ perspective and feel empathy. Easily replicability, official memoranda of understanding (MOUs) have been signed with the Royal Kingdom of Bhutan and the Republic of Maldives, where a2i provided technical assistance in several areas, including implementing the empathy training model.

Project Name: Maritime-Continental Silk Road Cities Alliance
Description: This initiative aimed to promote cooperation between port cities along the Maritime Silk Road in China and those on the African continent. The project aimed to increase trade and investment between the two regions and improve infrastructure connectivity. It was developed to align with the cross-regional Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), which connects countries of Asia, Africa and Europe. Facilitated by the Maritime-Continental Silk Road Cities Alliance (MCSR CA) Business Council, a private sector member of the MCSR CA from Fujian Province, China invested in the Haiha District Industry Park of Tinh Quang Ninh in Viet Nam. The total number of Vietnamese employees in three provinces is over 20,000, helping to address local employment problems. Employees are also offered the opportunity to undertake training at headquarters in Mainland China.More investment projects between Fujian Province and Viet Nam have been proposed as a result of this investment. In line with the priority areas of the BRI, there was a Chongqing-Vienna Culture Festival in 2016 to promote people-to-people exchanges.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNOSSC,UNIDO,UNDP,CICETE

Project Name: Building Back Better for a Climate- Resilient Caribbean
Description: The project aimed to support Caribbean countries in building their resilience to climate change and natural disasters. The project focused on enhancing preparedness and response capacities, and improving infrastructure and building codes to withstand natural disasters. Government of China, UNDP and governments in Antigua and Barbuda and Dominica quickly kicked off a disaster restoration initiative to support building-back efforts on both islands.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP and respective governments

Project Name: Post-Disaster Emergency Response in South Asia
Description: The project aimed to enhance disaster response capacities in Bangladesh, Nepal, and Pakistan. The project provided training, equipment and technical expertise to enhance disaster response and reduce the impact of disasters. Government of China partnered with UNDP to provide financial assistance to Bangladesh, Nepal and Pakistan through the South-South Cooperation Assistance Fund.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP and respective governments

Project Name: Strengthening Disaster Risk Management in Malawi
Description: UNDP China and the Chinese Ministry of Commerce formulated and approved a new disaster risk management project with the government of Malawi. The trilateral cooperation project aims to increase community resilience to flooding in disaster-affected districts through the introduction of rural communities to technically feasible, locally available, and environmentally implementable and socially responsible disaster risk management solutions.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,Governments of Malawi and China

Project Name: Technology Transfer of a Micro- Hydroelectric Energy System
Description: The project aimed to provide micro-hydroelectric power to remote rural communities in Haiti, thus improving access to electricity and reducing reliance on fossil fuels. Global Environmental Facility Small Grants Programme (GEF SGP) Haiti initiated a South-South cooperation exchange with GEF SGP Dominican Republic to draw on the latter__ expertise in establishing a community-led micro- hydroelectric system.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF Small Grants Programme,Guaki_a Ambiente (NGO)

Project Name: Promoting Seaweed Farming as a Sustainable Enterprise
Description: The project aimed to promote the sustainable cultivation of seaweed in Colombia, Cuba and Belize as an alternative livelihood for coastal communities. Global Environment Facility-Small Grant Programme (GEF SGP) , UNDP and United Nations Foundation provided a grant to PPCSL to pilot a project on commercial seaweed cultivation in Belize and then replicted this project in Colombia, Cuba. There were exchanges between Colombia and Belize, and than shared the experience with Cuba.

Project Name: Benin and Burkina Faso: How to Improve Shea Butter Production and Combat Land Degradation
Description: The project aimed to promote sustainable shea butter production, which has economic benefits for local communities and helps to combat land degradation caused by unsustainable agricultural practices. To improve local shea production in Benin, a South-South exchange between Benin and Burkina Faso took place, during which participating Beninese farmers learned how to significantly shorten the production cycle of shea.

Project Name: United Nations Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia (SPECA): Sub-regional cooperation to achieve 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development
Description: The project aimed to improve access to vocational training in Central Asia, thereby enhancing the employability of youth and contributing to sustainable economic development. The Chu-Talas Water Commission (CTWC) aims to achieve equitable sharing and use of water and benefited all of Central Asia. The SPECA experience is replicable in other regions and river basins. UNDP suported Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan to develope a Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) and a Strategic Action Programme (SAP).

Project Name: Regional Joint Project on Partnership for a Green Economy
Description: The Partnership for Action on Green Economy (PAGE) was launched in 2013 as a response to the Rio+20 call to support those countries wishing to embark on greener and more inclusive growth trajectories.The project aimed to promote sustainable development and green economy initiatives in several countries (China, Mongolia, Burkina Faso, Barbados), by supporting policy development and capacity building. China, Mongolia, Burkina Faso, Barbados were directly benefited from the PAGE projects on green development. The Partnership for Action on Green Economy (PAGE) seeks the promotion of South-South and triangular industrial cooperation as a mechanism to foster inclusive green economy through the exchange of knowledge on inclusive green economy, including exchanges and visits to PAGE partner countries.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: Government of Finland,Norway,the Republic of Korea,Sweden,Switzerland,European Union,and the UN Multi-Partner Trust Fund,UNEP,ILO,UNDP,UNIDO,UNITAR

Project Name: South-South Global Thinkers: The Global Coalition of Think Tank Networks for South-South Cooperation
Description: The South-South Global Thinkers is a community where think tank networks from the Global South and the North come together to engage in policy dialogues, share knowledge, expertise and most importantly Southern perspectives. The project aimed to promote knowledge sharing and collaboration among think tanks mainly from developing countries (over 200), thus contributing to the achievement of sustainable development goals. South-South Global Thinkers, the Global Coalition of Think Tank Networks for South-South Cooperation. This initiative brings together six think tank networks, totalling more than 200 think tanks from across all regions.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNOSSC,UNDP,More than 200 think tanks from across all regions.

Project Name: YouthConnekt Africa: A Youth Empowerment Programme in Africa
Description: This project - YouthConnekt took a __latform approach_ to solving challenging development issues, and brings together a wide range of stakeholders, including heads of states, business leaders, development partners and the civil society, to address the multiple needs of young people while also fully involving them in the solution-building process. YouthConnekt is a youth empowerment programme that was launched in Rwanda in 2012 and is currently being rolled out across Africa (see recipent countries). Indeed, inspired by the achievements of the YouthConnekt Rwanda initiative, several other African countries with the support of UNDP country offices have demonstrated strong interest in learning about YCA model. As a result, YouthConnekt has scaled up beyond Rwanda to 21 African countries.In many cases, partners simply integrated YouthConnekt components into ongoing programmes and as such also benefited by amplifying their initiatives through the programme. YCA is a great example of how local partnerships pave the way for regional partnership which eventually help YouthConnekt Rwanda to be YouthConnekt Africa. Private sectors contributed to this project.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,Korea International Cooperation Agency (KOICA),African Development Bank,African Union,Deut- sche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ),Ministry of Youth,Government of Rwanda

Project Name: The Use of Digital Technology to Improve Vaccine Delivery in India and Indonesia
Description: The Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network (eVIN) is a digital mobile and web-based system that enables real-time visibility of the vaccine supply chain and cold-chain logistics. It provides end-to-end tracking of vaccine inventory, automated data analytics and instant alerts to support quick and effective decision-making and action. The project promoted access and delivery of health technologies through the South-South exchange of innovative technology, knowledge and solutions. UNDP established a knowledge hub in India to promote South-South engagement and cooperation on eVIN (Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network) and other digital health and supply chain management aspects.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,Gavi the Vaccine Alliance, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India),Ministry of Health (Indonesia)

Project Name: The Vocational Education and Training Programme for the Member States of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC)
Description: The project aimed to enhance vocational education and training among Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) member states by developing policies and guidelines, building capacities, and improving access to quality vocational education and training.The programme was designed to scale up SSTC and knowledge exchange through innovative and holistic approaches among the relevant national Vocational Education and Training Programme authorities of the Member States. To assess the needs of technical and vocational education systems in the OIC Member States, SESRIC, in cooperation with six international institutions, including UNDP IICPSD and 24 OIC Member States, developed the OIC-TVET Strategic Roadmap 2020_2025. OIC institutions and UN agencies had significant roles in supporting the OIC-VET with their valuable inputs, which illustrated effective SSC and TrC among all stakeholders working hand in hand for the success and sustainability of this good practice.

Project Name: Curbing Child Marriage Using Technology
Description: In the project, it utilized a mobile phone-based system to help prevent child marriages in Bangladesh by providing young girls and their families with information, support, and referral services. Project Name: Forum of Small States (FOSS) for Good Technical Assistance Package
Description: In 1992, Singapore founded the Forum of Small States (FOSS) and championed it as a platform for small states to discuss and share issues of common interest. This project is a platform that provides technical assistance and capacity building to small states in the Global South, offering access to a range of tools and services, such as policy advice, training, and mentoring on issues related to sustainable development, climate change, and economic growth. To mark the 30th anniversary of FOSS in 2022, Singapore launched the __OSS for Good_ technical assistance package under the Singapore Cooperation Programme (SCP), a platform to extend technical assistance for fellow developing countries. The SCP has hosted close to 150,000 foreign government officials from 180 countries, territories and inter-governmental organisations in its programmes. In the spirit of mutual cooperation to foster collective growth, the __OSS for Good_ package aims to provide a peer-learning platform for government officials from FOSS member states to share experiences and best practices, and adapt the knowledge learnt to their own countries, based on their own national circumstances. The package, which will run from 2022 to 2023, focuses on member states_ vital development priorities such as digital transformation and COVID-19 recovery. To further support solidarity amongst FOSS, Singapore will offer sponsorship to all FOSS states under the package regardless of their development status.A peer-learning platform for government officials from FOSS member states to share experiences and best practices and adapt the knowledge learned to their own countries based on their own national circumstances. Finally, two Customised Programmes were conducted in Singapore in July 2022. 28 participants from 20 countries took part in these two programmes.

It supported the development of a professional and competent civil service capable of effectively delivering services to the citizens. This was achieved through the deployment of 200 civil servants from Ethiopia, Kenya, and Uganda to South Sudan in key functions identified by the Government of South Sudan. This triangular-organized, donor-supported South-South cooperation model focused on coaching and mentoring for civil service capacity. The deployments served as a capacity boost, facilitating the development of local capacity through peer-to-peer coaching partnerships with South Sudanese counterparts. During the project's first phase, technical support was provided for institutional strengthening by formulating legal, regulatory, and policy frameworks. This included the enactment of regulations governing the conduct of business by the National Legislative Assembly. Additionally, the project helped harmonize and develop sectoral policies to support various Ministries in South Sudan. The model of triangular-organized, donor-supported South-South cooperation in coaching and mentoring for civil service capacity has been gradually promoted for fragile states, recognizing the benefits of involving neighboring countries with cultural and linguistic affinity, as well as knowledge of local and regional conditions. Moreover, the Initiative offers a cost-effective approach, with an average cost of around $50,000 per civil service support officer per year, encompassing all project expenses.

Description: The project facilitated cooperation between African countries to promote sustainable water management and the conservation of shared water resources. Global and regional workshops under the Convention, for example, on transboundary water cooperation in Africa, support a South-South capacity-building approach to accelerate progress towards the SDGs. For example, the 2019 __ractitioner to Practitioner:  Regional Training on Promoting Implementation to Two Global Water Conventions_ workshop, organized by UNECE together with partners targeting experts active in Francophone countries in West, North and Central Africa, fostered a common understanding on the practical benefits of both the Water Convention and the Convention on the Law of Non-Navigational Uses of International Watercourses (commonly referred to as the Watercourses Convention), collectively known as the United Nations global water conventions. The first report on the global baseline for SDG indicator 6.5.2 published in 2018 demonstrated that the highest level of cooperation can be found in the Pan-European region, largely facilitated by the Water Convention, followed by West and Southern Africa, including, for example, Senegal, the Gambia, Volta and Niger Rivers. Description: The project aimed to addressing the socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 in Portuguese-speaking African countries through innovation and South-South cooperation E-volve (E-voluir) was an innovation competition and programme that put forward creative solutions to development challenges exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Fábrica de Startups Brasil, a business accelerator, implementing the project across the PALOPs with full financing from UNDP in Guinea-Bissau and technical support from UNDP country offices in Angola, Cabo Verde, Mozambique and São Tomé e Príncipe, as well as from Guinea-Bissau. The competition was an opportunity for citizens of the PALOPs to come forward and propose ideas and solutions to socioeconomic problems affecting their communities, mainly in areas related to: (i) work and economy; (ii) e-governance and digital transformation; (iii) disaster risk reduction; and (iv) community resilience.The initiative attracted more than 1,000 applications in the ideation phase from young professionals and graduate students from both PALOP resident nationals and members of the diasporas. Ten teams were eventually selected, each composed of three to four participants. In partnership with Fábrica de Startups Brasil, E-volve provided support to the selected startups, starting with an intensive ideation week for the development of solutions in February 2021. The ideation week was followed by a 20-week acceleration programme, during which the winning teams were joined by ten early-stage startups from the PALOPs that already work on similar challenges. Throughout E-volve, participating teams were put in contact with mentors and possible funding and technical partners. The initiative has shown that, even during a pandemic, it is possible to organize an online innovation journey, focusing on network development and on South-South cooperation. Although the initiative dealt with immediate solutions to the COVID-19 crisis, it also has potential long-term impacts, including the intensification of South-South cooperation among the PALOPs through exchanges of best practices and strengthening of Lusophone entrepreneurship ecosystems and innovation networks.

Project Name: __uilding trust and confidence in Zimbabwe__ Transition_ Project, learning from South Africa
Description: The project "Building trust and confidence in Zimbabwe's Transition" was a joint program among UNDP, UN WOMEN, and UNICEF. It aimed to develop a common framework for implementing the peace architecture in the country. The project, facilitated by UNDP Zimbabwe, sought technical advice from the Humanitarian Dialogue in Kenya to assist the National Peace and Reconciliation Commission (NPRC) in Zimbabwe in establishing the Conflict Early Warning and Early Response (CEWER) system. This technical assistance played a crucial role in shaping the discourse on the development of indicators and the selection of a contextualized prototype system for Zimbabwe. Moreover, the NPRC benefited from the experience of South Africa in conducting public hearings. A former commissioner of the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission shared knowledge and lessons with the NPRC. These lessons focused on various aspects such as the development of training manuals, the methodology for conducting public hearings, and the establishment of information storage and security facilities. This valuable knowledge, along with provincial stakeholder consultations, has informed the NPRC's policy on public hearings. This collaboration between different UN agencies, as well as the sharing of experiences with South Africa, exemplifies the spirit of SSC in fostering peace and reconciliation efforts in Zimbabwe.

Project Name: UNDP Africa Sustainable Finance Hub (ASFH)'s support to SSTC
Description: Several online inter-regional South-South events (symposium, workshops, etc.) were organized by ASFH in 2020 with the participation of about 40 African countries. They served as SSC platforms for peer-learning and exchanging ideas and good practices on enhancing domestic revenue mobilization, boosting remittances, and strengthening SSC institutionalization for African countries in the COVID-19 context and beyond. Examples included: the regional taxation symposium __nhancing Domestic Revenue Mobilization for Sustainable Development in Africa-Dialogue on Taxation, Social Contract and Post COVID-19 Recovery Strategy; and a regional south-south workshop on remittances in 2020: Boosting remittances in the current COVID-19 context and beyond.

Project Name: Enhancing Domestic Revenue Mobilization for Sustainable Development in Africa: Dialogue on Taxation, Social Contract and Post COVID-19 Recovery Strategy
Description: African countries face challenges in collecting due tax revenue, including low tax morale, inefficient administration, tax avoidance/evasion, and dependence on natural resource revenue. These challenges limit their ability to use taxes effectively for COVID-19 mitigation and sustainable development.UNDP and AfronomicsLaw organised an event to discuss taxation in Africa, focusing on trends, challenges, and solutions for effective revenue mobilization. The outcome informed UNDP's support to governments and guide regional and global taxation efforts. The webinar, "Enhancing Domestic Revenue Mobilization for Sustainable Development in Africa: Dialogue on Taxation, Social Contract and Post COVID-19 Recovery Strategy" held on 10, November, 2020 counted with the participation and discussions on taxation from Togo, Honduras, Maldives, South Africa, Jamaica, Zambia, Uganda, and Finland. Representatives and officials from these countries shared their insights, experiences, and recommendations on various tax-related issues and reforms. The UNDP Africa Finance Sector Hub plans to collect these recommendations to develop a continent-wide project to support countries in enhancing domestic revenue mobilization for the realization of the SDGs.

The South-South Virtual Seminar "Boosting Remittances in the current COVID-19 context and beyond" aimed to understand remittance challenges, explore opportunities for COVID-19 recovery and sustainable development financing, and generate dialogue. Inputs gathered would inform the development of UNDP's FSH Africa Regional Project on Remittances in Africa. To understand remittance challenges, engage stakeholders, promote dialogue, and develop a roadmap for UNDP's FSH Africa Regional Project, representatives from the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Ethiopia, Benin, Moldova, Mexico, Nigeria, Cabo Verde, Kenya, and the Philippines shared their experiences and perspectives. Project Name: Morocco 4C - Blue Congo Basin Fund
Description: 2020 saw the culmination of the foreshadowing study of the Blue Fund for the Congo Basin, the result of UNDP Morocco's support to the Climate Change Competence Center (4C Morocco) as part of a SSC agreement between the Kingdom of Morocco and the Congo Basin Climate Commission. The study, allowed to identify a pipeline of more than 250 structuring projects stemming from the 24 sectoral programs of the Blue Economy and Nationally Determined Contributions (CDN), valued at about US $ 9 billion, and on the other hand, to define the financial mechanism of the Fund and its governance model. Project Name: Establishing an Organic Certification System in the Caribbean
Description: In 2014, the major organic agricultural association in Barbados, the Organic Growers and Consumers Association (OGCA),  received support to establish a national organic inspection and certification system. The project focused on building capacity among association members for certification and meeting organic standards. OGCA recognized the potential for regional collaboration, particularly with Jamaica's experience in organic farming. They aimed to create a Caribbean network to develop local and regional capacity for a regional organic protocol. The exchange between Jamaica Organic Association Movement (JOAM) and OCGA aimed to implement a national organic inspection and certification system in Barbados based on JOAM's experience. JOAM connected OCGA with the International Organic Inspectors Association (IOIA) to provide training and ensure consistency in the certification process. JOAM also facilitated collaboration with the Grenada Organic Agriculture Movement (GOAM) to expand the South-South cooperation and involve GOAM members in training Barbadian inspectors with support from GEF SGP.

Project Name: China-Malawi-UNDP disaster management
Description: The project is part of the China-Africa-UNDP Cooperation Programme and focuses on reducing the impact of natural disasters, particularly flooding, in rural Malawi. It aims to enhance community resilience and introduce sustainable disaster risk management solutions. The project has resulted in the construction of evacuation centers, dike and riverbank protection, and check dams, benefiting over 23,000 people. Additionally, disaster risk management has been integrated into policies and development plans, data and knowledge on natural disasters have been collected, and coordination mechanisms have been established at national and district levels. This project reflects China's commitment to deepening cooperation with developing countries, as outlined in the 2010 Memorandum of Understanding with UNDP.

The workshop aimed to explore effective approaches to managing disaster risks and strengthen community engagement in disaster management. Stakeholders from the U.K., China, Bangladesh, and Nepal participated in thought-provoking discussions during the two-day event. The workshop emphasized the importance of multi-stakeholder partnerships, regional cooperation, and disaster risk reduction in achieving SDGs and the 2030 agenda for sustainable development. The event provided an opportunity to consolidate partnerships, share experiences, and envision a more sustainable network for disaster management practitioners across governments, communities, academia, international organizations, and the private sector in the four countries.

Project Name: Improving the climate resilience of Kazakhstan's wheat and enhancing a regional dialogue on Central Asian food security
Description: The Central Asian Republics, including Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, and Uzbekistan, face challenges related to their fragile natural resource base, and regional tensions hindering cooperation. Food security in the region is vulnerable due to a heavy reliance on wheat production, especially in Kazakhstan, which is a major exporter. The Central Asian countries heavily import Kazakh wheat, with spikes in food prices contributing to food insecurity. However, Kazakhstan's wheat sector is susceptible to climate change, posing a threat to regional food security. To address these issues, UNDP Kazakhstan implemented a project called "Improving the Climate Resiliency of Kazakhstan Wheat and Central Asian Food Security" with support from a $1 million grant from USAID. The project aimed to facilitate adaptation in Kazakhstan's wheat sector and stimulate a regional dialogue on climate change challenges and food security in Central Asia. The grant had three main components: Improved Information for Climate-Resilient, Mainstreaming Climate Resilience into Wheat Production in Kazakhstan, Regional Dialogue on Wheat, Climate Change and Regional Food Security.

Project Name: COVID-19 Recovery in Lebanon
Description: Promote post COVID-19 recovery and poverty reduction through productive expansion for women and youth in Lebanon. The Government of China and UNDP have joined forces in Lebanon to support COVID-19 socio-economic recovery, with a focus on women and youth. Through the South-South Cooperation Assistance Fund, funded by China, UNDP aims to develop sustainable livelihoods and economic opportunities by providing business development services and access to markets. Lebanon is currently facing a complex crisis, leading to increased poverty rates and unemployment, particularly among women and youth. This partnership aims to improve the livelihoods of women and youth, enhance the capacity of MSMEs and cooperatives, strengthen business development services, expand access to markets through an e-commerce platform, and facilitate access to the Chinese market. The goal is to mitigate the impact of the crises and ensure that no one is left behind. This collaboration reflects the longstanding partnership between UNDP and the Government of China, focusing on global development issues and private sector engagement.

The project supports poor and vulnerable communities by implementing small grant projects proposed by NGOs and local community groups. Its objectives include increasing community resilience, introducing disaster risk management solutions, and promoting sustainable development. The project has achieved outcomes such as constructing evacuation centers, implementing flood control measures, and improving disaster risk management at the national and district levels. These efforts have directly benefited over 23,000 people and improved the management of the environment and natural resources.

The training program was attended by over 80 representatives from local governments in Ecuador. MELA training was initially a regional initiative that started in Türkiye and was followed by a program in Palestine. Later, the program continued to spread beyond the MEWA Region and started to become a global initiative. The Azerbaijan edition of the training was held with the cooperation of Eurasian section of UCLG, and the Albania edition was held with the cooperation of European section of UCLG. MELA training program will be helpful for Local Authorities to encourage and support the development of municipal enterprises to take advantage of capacity and create an ecosystem to attract the private sector that will provide sustainability, resilience and inclusion in the provision of municipal services, under the Win-Win philosophy.To respond to the development challenges, IICPSD, under its Harnessing the Role of Private Sector for Inclusive Urbanization portfolio, provides evidence-based research to identify good practices to be replicated and scaled-up in LDCs and emerging markets. The Center also offers technical assistance and capacity building activities and builds multi-stakeholder partnerships to engage and harness private sector in leveraging sustainable, inclusive and resilient cities. With an aim at leveraging the SSTC and maximize its impact on sustainable development. IICPSD will continue its effort to raise awareness on the role of private sector for inclusive urbanization by conducting its MELA training program for the local authorities in the global south.

Project Name: Strengthening the capacity of the League of Arab States
Description: UNDP__ focus has been on strengthening the capacity of the League of Arab States (LAS) to initiate and facilitate cooperation among its member states and other stakeholders, in the face of a crisis deriving from the COVID-19 pandemic. Project Name: African South-South and Triangular Cooperation Responses to COVID-19 and Beyond
Description: UNDP's SDG Finance Hub in Africa, in collaboration with UNOSSC, has produced a report titled "African South-South and Triangular Cooperation Responses to COVID-19 and Beyond." The report showcases how African countries have developed coordinated and collaborative responses to COVID-19 and beyond through South-South and Triangular Cooperation (SSCTC) for sustainable development. The report focuses on the utilization of SSC and TrC to facilitate a COVID-19 response and how these approaches can contribute to strengthening COVID-19 recovery efforts in the future. It targets a wide range of African stakeholders and aims to generate momentum in the use of SSC/TrC, while fostering knowledge exchange on innovative solutions. By highlighting ongoing initiatives, the report seeks to promote the scaling up of national experiences at the regional and global levels. Additionally, it highlights the ways in which UNDP can provide support to these endeavors.

It was organised by ACRC and UNDP Country Offices (COs) of Mongolia, Kosovo and Uzbekistan. The Clean Portal is an innovative digital platform developed and operated by ACRC for reporting corruption and public interest violations. It serves as a one-stop anti-corruption platform for 1,042 public organizations in Korea, providing an effective tracking and monitoring system, in addition to information on rewards and protection provided to whistleblowers, and anti-corruption policies. Project Name: Sharing Innovative Experiences: Successful Social Protection Floor Experiences

The publication was produced in partnership between the former Special Unit for SSC in UNDP and the International Labour Organization (ILO). This volume highlights 18 case studies on social protection policies from 15 countries of the global South. It is the first to bring together examples of good social protection floor practices for South-South learning. The knowledge, expertise and experience that these countries have gained in their own efforts of establishing an SPF represent a valuable source for other countries interested in planning, expanding, extending or reorienting their own SPF (Social Protection Floor) systems. The Indonesian government has established a national energy strategy to increase clean energy supply to at least 23% by 2025, and in order to fulfil the goal, it has been exerting its efforts to improve energy access in remote areas. Therefore, the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia has made an official request to KOICA for a solar energy initiative and the Ministry of Public Works of Timor-Leste offered full co-operation including selection of project site. Through the project activities such as developing business model of community participation, fostering start-up business of system operation, and building infrastructure for appropriate solar technology, it is expected to generate economic and social value in the region and contribute to enhance the living condition of the vulnerable groups by targeting energy poverty region in Indonesia and Timor-Leste. Project Name: Efficient Land Management for Socio-Economic Enhancement in Southern Nepal (Phase II)
Description: This project aimed to introduce the systematic cultivation of waste and fallow land and to improve the livelihood of marginalized women farmers in Southern Nepal. To introduce improved cultivation methods to over 3,700 households in deprived rural communities in Nepal, and in addition, indirectly 18,500 households in the region. The project has supported farmers to gain knowledge about efficient farming technologies and practices to improve irrigation and mobilize the unproductive land. Female farmers specifically have been provided with improved technical knowledge on irrigation and farming practices to maintain during in the dry season, which has enabled them to increase their agricultural yields. Additionally, husbands have returned from the neighbouring cities in Nepal and India to work for their wives in the field. With support from this project women have been able to reduce their dependency on their husbands, pay off debt and provide quality health and education for their children.

Description: To learn from Georgia about agricultural cooperatives, extension and farming services and agricultural policy frameworks. The EU and UNDP support for rural development in Georgia draws on the EUR179.5 million EU-funded European Neighbourhood Programme for Agriculture and Rural Development (ENPARD) implemented since 2013. Project Name: South-South Cooperation between Pacific and Caribbean SIDS on Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Management project
Description: The program aims to consolidate linkages among small island states facing common risks and draw on the experiences and cooperation of both South-South and North-South partners to strengthen resilience and address climate-related challenges. The SSC Unit at UNDP Bangkok Regional Centre provides technical assistance and develops knowledge products to support the program and offers guidance on community-based disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation. The Japanese government assists SIDS, particularly in enhancing climate change adaptation. While the initial focus is on consolidating exchanges between the Pacific and the Caribbean, other SIDS such as the Maldives and Mauritius are included, as they can contribute valuable insights based on their shared concerns and risks. These countries will be encouraged to participate in virtual discussions to enrich the program's outcomes. In addition to SSC, the program will leverage relevant expertise and lessons. Synergies will be sought with Japan as a triangular partner, given its recognition of the project's value and its own experience as an island state facing similar hazards. Japan can provide insights into community-oriented disaster awareness materials, community resilience building, and traditional coping practices. Australia and New Zealand, with their extensive involvement in climate change science and disaster risk management in the Pacific, can also contribute to the program. The program will specifically seek to link with the Cool Earth Partnership promoted by Japan, which covers the Maldives as well as the following countries in the Caribbean and the Pacific: Guyana, Haiti, Suriname, Belize, and Dominican Republic in the Caribbean; and Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Micronesia, Nauru, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu in the Pacific.

Project Name: Ecofish Programme
Description: The Ecofish Programme, funded by the Eleventh European Development Fund, is a collaborative effort involving the five Indian Ocean Commission (IOC) member states (the Union of the Comoros, France on behalf of Reunion, Madagascar, Mauritius and Seychelles), three ESA countries (Kenya, Mozambique, and the United Republic of Tanzania), the European Union (EU) Delegation to Mauritius, the Duly Mandated Regional Organisation, regional fisheries bodies, and various development partners. The project aims to enhance the sustainable management of inland and marine fisheries in the ESA-IO region. The implementation of the programme is led by UNDP in partnership with the Ministry of Blue Economy, Marine Resources, Fisheries, and Shipping. The primary beneficiaries of the programme are the 22 countries of the African, Caribbean, and Pacific Group of States, including Kenya, Mozambique, Tanzania, Mauritius, Madagascar, Seychelles, and Somalia. The overarching goal of the Ecofish Programme is to promote economic efficiency, social equity, and environmental integrity in the region. Through coordinated efforts and cooperation, the programme seeks to address the challenges of overfishing, unsustainable fishing practices, and environmental degradation. By advancing sustainable fisheries management, the programme aims to benefit local communities, improve livelihoods, and safeguard marine ecosystems.

Description: The project is funded by Global Development and South-South Cooperation Fund (GDF). Description: The Project aims to work closely with the Government to set up Common Facility Centres where Small and Medium Entreprises are looking to diversify their products and scale-up production of highly demanded Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) to sell in the local market and potentially export can gain access to training, modern machinery including transfer of technology from China. Project Name: Promoting Seaweed Farming as a Sustainable Enterprise: Belize and Colombia
Description: In 2009, Placencia Producers Cooperative Society Limited (PPCSL) fishers in Belize received grants from GEF SGP to start a pilot project on commercial seaweed cultivation in Placencia, Belize. The project was successful, leading to the establishment of 20 seaweed farms, market development, and a partnership with Coral Caye Ltd. to expand the industry. They continue to improve cultivation methods and explore new revenue streams.The South-South cooperation exchange involved training Colombian fishers in seaweed cultivation techniques at the farms of PPCSL in Belize. The exchange included presentations on seaweed aquaculture, hands-on training in farm design and construction, and selecting the best seeds for high yields. The initiative has been replicated by other organizations in Belize. Additionally, GEF SGP Belize hosted another exchange with a Cuban delegation to share knowledge on sponge cultivation, coral nurseries, and seaweed cultivation.

Project Name: How to improve shea butter production and combat land degradation: Benin and Burkina Faso
Description: To improve local shea production in Benin, the NGO Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination (CERD)-BENIN requested support from the international NGO TREE AID of Burkina Faso.  From January to February 2013, a South-South exchange between Benin and Burkina Faso took place, during which participating Beninese farmers learned how to significantly shorten the production cycle of shea, an exceedingly slow-growing species that takes about 25 to 30 years to reach productive maturity, through a grafting process. With the technical support of an agricultural engineer at TREE AID, the Beninese farmers learned how to use assisted natural regeneration to improve their trees_ productive capacity. By establishing a system for rotating the branches to ensure stable fruit yield, they were able to increase shea butter production by 3 tonnes in two years, at a rate of 1.5 tonnes per year. The Beninese producers also learned how to naturally control parasitic plants, which are a considerable hindrance to shea production. Finally, in Burkina Faso, farmers had come up with the idea of rigorously harvesting the Tapinenthus, a genus of mistletoe.

Project Name: Empowering women to become solar engineers and bring light to the world
Description: Since 2008, the GEF Small Grants Programme has been working with Barefoot College to support __omen Solar Engineers_ projects across Africa, Asia and Latin America and the Caribbean. In this collaborative effort, Barefoot College offers six-months of training to the women on their campus in Tilonia, India, while SGP provides technical and financial support to electrify their villages and maintain the equipment in the long run. As a result, 71 women were empowered and achieved better social status by bringing renewable energy to more than 52 villages worldwide, benefitting more than 20,000 people. Similar initiatives have been replicated in neighboring villages and scaled-up by other national and donor programmes. The exchanges are transformational, not only in bringing about results on the ground, but also in creating long-lasting bonds and partnerships across communities and countries. Through the SSC exchanges, the initiative advances gender equality, economically empowering women, and provides poor, off-the-grid communities with clean, low-cost solar energy and electricity.

Project Name: Energy efficient cook stove technology exchange: United Republic of Tanzania and Kenya
Description: In 2014, with support from the Small Grants Programme, the International Collaborative for Science, Education, and the Environment (ICSEE) created a project called__he Maasai Stoves Project.__he project aims to improve Maasai indoor air quality by supporting the manufacturing of clean-burning and efficient stoves. In July 2014, a group of Maasai women from Kenya visited their relatives in Tanzania and discovered improved cook stoves that were more efficient and environmentally friendly. Impressed, they approached ICSEE, an NGO, to help them adopt the new model in Kenya. With support from SGP, ICSEE organized an exchange in June 2015, where Tanzanian Maasai women and NGO facilitators went to Kenya to demonstrate stove installation and train the Kenyan Maasai women in stove construction and maintenance.

Project Name: Experience in mangrove conservation and resilience to climate change: India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, Thailand, and the Philippines
Description: Several countries, including India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, Thailand, and the Philippines, have extensive experience in mangrove conservation and building resilience to climate change. The HANDs Project, supported by GEF SGP and the Japan Foundation, facilitated an exchange program among youth from India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, the Philippines, and Thailand. The project aimed to foster community and coexistence by encouraging creative solutions to social and environmental issues. Participants visited the mangrove forest in Baan Bang La and engaged in discussions on sustainable management and resilience against natural disasters.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF SGP

Project Name: Strengthening the International Network of Mountain Indigenous Peoples
Description: The International Network of Mountain Indigenous Peoples (INMIP) was established to support capacity building and knowledge sharing among mountain indigenous peoples in establishing and implementing Biocultural Heritage Territories (BCHTs) to adapt to climate change. The network includes ten participating countries and various organizations working on sustainable mountain management. GEF SGP has been a key partner since 2014, supporting INMIP's activities through funding and collaboration with other stakeholders. The project focuses on raising awareness, exchanging experiences, building capacity, and promoting collaboration with governments for sustainable mountain development.INMIP utilizes horizontal learning methods such as walking workshops and biocultural festivals to facilitate knowledge exchange at a global level. GEF SGP has played a significant role in organizing and supporting several international exchanges, including events in Bhutan, China, and Peru. These exchanges focused on topics such as biocultural adaptation, traditional water management systems, participatory plant breeding, and community planning, with the aim of establishing resilient biocultural landscapes and empowering indigenous peoples.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF SGP

Project Name: Preventing desertification by using renewable and energy efficient technologies: Chile, El Salvador, Honduras and Uruguay
Description: The Small Grants Programme in Chile has collaborated with local communities and grantees for 18 years to develop climate change technologies. These include energy-efficient stoves, solar ovens, solar dryers, and various types of ovens. Traditional recipes have also been adapted to work with these technologies, focusing on improving nutritional value and community health. In 2013, SGP Chile initiated a South-South cooperation project with El Salvador to combat land degradation through energy-efficient and renewable technologies. Funding was sought from UNDP Chile, and a cooperation exchange was facilitated in coordination with Canelo Corporation from Chile. In June and July 2015, the NGO El Canelo from Chile, along with professionals from the UNDP-EU programme, conducted training in Uruguay to teach three communities how to construct renewable technologies such as energy-efficient cook stoves (magic pots), solar ovens, and dryers. The exchange was supported by SGP GEF UNDP El Salvador and Uruguay, and the activities were documented by the Uruguayan NGO CEUTA through videos and manuals for further dissemination. Similar exchanges between Chile, El Salvador, and Uruguay have taken place to combat desertification and promote sustainable technologies. SGP Honduras expressed interest in adopting the technologies used by SGP El Salvador, building upon their longstanding cooperation. To facilitate this, 31 women from the El Venado community were selected by SGP Honduras and received training from technicians representing El Canelo NGO, the Chilean Government, and the National Coordinator of SGP El Salvador.The exchanges were funded by the Chilean Fund and involved multiple communities and organizations.
Entity/ies Supporting and/or Implementin: UNDP,GEF SGP

Project Name: UNDP's Suppport to Emerging Donors
Description: Over the past 15 years, the UNDP's Regional Center in Europe and Central Asia has a portfolio of programmatic engagement with strategic donor partners in RBEC region, including the Russian Federation, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Turkey, Poland, Romania, Serbia, and Montenegro to strengthen their official development assistance (ODA) systems. This includes training national ODA experts, implementing impactful projects, and providing assistance to emerging donors in developing tailored ODA legal, institutional, and strategic frameworks. Notable achievements include the approval of new ODA laws in Romania and Kazakhstan, as well as the establishment of development cooperation agencies like RoAid in Romania and SlovakAid in the Slovak Republic. UNDP continues to support development cooperation agencies in enhancing their internal regulatory frameworks, including ODA financial and implementation guidelines, as well as Results-Based Management (RBM) manuals and toolkits. These partnerships aim to test and implement various forms and modalities of South-South and triangular cooperation (SSTC), leveraging UNDP's field presence and network of partners. Cooperation with country offices serves as a conduit to connect with UNDP's partners, Accelerator Labs, and various implementation modalities for triangular cooperation in areas such as public finance, innovation, and digital transformation.

Project Name: Umbrella Programme For Socio-Economic Development - Project ID: 137889 / Output ID: 128132
Description: This project was designed to support, mainstreaming social and economic development in the national policies in Saudi Arabia and to strengthen evidence-based policy planning and decision-making to support the realization of Saudi Vision 2030 and the SDGs. As a result, UNDP and MEP have agreed to adopt an approach to address, simultaneously, short and long-term demands supporting effective implementation of the SDGs as well as improving policymaking and ensuring policy coherence to facilitate the achievement of the social and economic transformation in Saudi Arabia. UNDP will support the various deputyships in MEP, prioritising the technical support needed to strengthen MEP's role related to tackling complex cross-cutting policy issues. The project will utilize North-South and South-South Cooperation modalities in support of the intended outcomes. A South-South Cooperation arrangement will be reached jointly with identified countries of best practices in the regional development and regional competitiveness. Later, a list of possible international best practices will be compiled based on the comprehensive review of the regional development patterns. " Experts could not travel on location and worked remotely, this impeded some of the work. The Implementation of the Umbrella Programme for Socio-Economic Development had been slowed due to change of National Project Manager several times, in addition to COVID-19 implications. The Umbrella Programme had undergone a substantive revision to further align it with the Saudi Vision 2030, the SDGs and to better address new socio-economic development challenges due to COVID-19. 2020 was spent entirely to revise the overall framework. The new framework is envisioned to serve as a roadmap from 2021 _ 2024 starting with 2021 as a pilot for the newly envisioned engagement with Ministry. UNDP support will be built around four pillars for 2021: SDGs, Policy Support and Technical Assistance, Human development reporting and the study of unemployment and policy recommendations, Training and Development, The training and expansion of the programme agreed upon was delayed because of budgeting issues"
